We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between the two methods for the outcomes examined in this review. Results suggest that the effectiveness of indirect pulp therapy may be affected by the number of studies it receives and the method used.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of human insulin in diabetic patients with type 1 (insulin-dependent) diabetes.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of anthypertensive of patients with essential hypertension with the drug in patients with mild to moderate hypertension. The results suggest that theorta of anthypertensive may be more effective than placebo in these people.

Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from oral fatty acids in patients with peripheral vascular disease and elevated cholesterol. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of omega-3 PUFAs in the treatment of peripheral vascular disease.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of triple therapy for the eradication of Helicobacter pylori in patients with duodenal ulcer.

Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from the administration of E2 and P prophylactically before transepidermal administration of these hormones is commenced. Further evidence is required from larger sample sizes and from contemporary evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of E2 and P replacement inversely to no replacement.
Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from steroid treatment in children with Crohn's disease.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between epoetin beta and epoetin for the outcomes examined in this review. Results suggest that the two groups of eligible CAPD patients may be more or less evenly matched in terms of treatment with epoetin. The results suggest that a more frequent and lower-dose administration of epoetin is effective in preventing and reversing renal anemia in affected patients. However, this is based on a small sample size and the absence of other relevant studies.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit has been gained from the use of salmeterol in patients with moderate- to-moderate asthma. The results suggest that the benefits of salmeterol may be under-quoted in some cases.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of pelvic radiation on cancer outcomes in women with cancer while the potential benefits of hydroxyurea may be under-discussed. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from contemporary trials is required in order to assess the effect of radiation on cancer outcomes in women with cancer properly.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of parenteral magnesium for the prevention of preterm labor in women treated with terbutaline.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between the two oral contraceptive formulations for the outcomes examined in this review. The results suggest that oral contraceptives containing ethinyl estradiol may improve bleeding when compared with no intervention or oral contraceptive.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of T-cell therapy with seratonin inhibitor in patients with advanced melanoma. The results suggest that the benefits of T-cell therapy may be under-quoted in some cases.
We have not found evidence that a significant benefit exists from the use of spinal cord stimulation in patients with severe leg ischaemia.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of quinine in the treatment of children with moderate malaria. The results suggest that intrarectal quinine could be effective in reducing malaria in affected areas. However, this is based on a small sample size and the current evidence base is limited. Further evidence is required to assess the effectiveness of quinine in larger and longer-term studies.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from catheter irrigation in people with neurogenic bladder.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of day psychiatric treatment compared to inpatient care for people with severe psychiatric illness. The results suggest that day hospital treatment is more effective than inpatient treatment in reducing symptoms, improving quality of life, and improving social functioning in affected people.

No evidence was found to support or overthrow current treatment regimes. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from larger and longer-term trials is required in order to assess the effectiveness of topical Pimozide therapy compared with no intervention or placebo in affected patients.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of olanzapine in the treatment of acute bipolar mania and was unable to detect clinically relevant differences between groups. Results suggest that a larger body of evidence could be gathered from the small numbers of studies comparing olanzapine with other antidepressants such as dopamine agonists and mono
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of antidepressants in the treatment of dysthymic disorders such as depression and anxiety.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of fluorouracil and doxorubicin in patients with advanced gastric cancer.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of chlorhexidine in preventing neonatal infection.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral polyp treatment with aspirin or placebo in the majority of people with colon cancer who are eligible for the study. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of oral polyp treatment with aspirin in the absence of other intervention such as colonoscopy or poly polyp burden.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of G-CSF in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The results suggest that the benefits of G-CSF may be under-quoted in some cases.

We have not found evidence that a reduction in drug use is significantly affected by the presence of psychotherapy in affected people. However, this could be because the data we have examined are scarce. We were unable to reach definite conclusions about any adverse effects that might result from the use of these interventions.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of interlock programs in reducing DUI recidivism while on the vehicle of the offender. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of interlock programs in other jurisdictions.

There is little evidence to suggest that the use of telephone consultations reduces patient attendance at the hospital or ER during the delivery of care. The results suggest that the use of telephone consultations may reduce hospitalizations or ER visits during the delivery of care. However, this is based on a small sample size and there is no evidence to suggest a reduction in patient rates of visits during the actual implementation of the intervention or in the subsequent years.
We have not found evidence that a benefit exists from the administration of penicillamine in primary sclerosing cholangitis.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit from brief intervention exists for pregnant women who do not report alcohol consumption or are unable to report it. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of such intervention in the future. Further evidence is required from larger and longer-term trials.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between EMLA and amethocaine Gel for the outcomes examined in this review. The results suggest that the use of amethocaine Gel is effective in reducing pain of needle puncture in children. However, this does not apply to the absence or absence of adverse effects.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of spinal manipulation in patients with cervical pain. The results suggest that manipulation may improve pain and active range of motion in affected areas of the neck.

We have not found evidence that a significant reduction in pain was achieved by the use of electromagnetic therapy in patients with myofascial pain. The results suggest that the benefits of PEMF may be more easily accessible in smaller groups than in larger studies.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of triflusal in the prevention of myocardial infarction in patients with unstable angina. The results suggest that triflusal may be effective in reducing the hemorrhagic complications that may result from the treatment of patients with unstable angina with AAS.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of folic acid on the seizures of affected children. The results suggest that the benefits of folic acid may be more easily appreciated in the context of larger studies.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of Quit intervention in smokeless tobacco users.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of Botulinum toxin type B in patients with cervical dystonia when compared with placebo.
We have not found evidence that a significant benefit exists from the use of oral testosterone in the suppression of spermatogenesis in men. This is based on a small sample of eligible men and women.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit from colon cancer has been lost or missed in patients withrectal cancer after resection.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of radiotherapy on survival of patients with localized NPC while improving cancer outcomes.

We have not found evidence that a reduction in injury rates was achieved by the implementation of booster seat intervention in preschool families. This is based on a small sample size and the absence of other evidence.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit from antiretroviral therapy is proportional to the number of people treated in the emergency department for HIV infection.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of catheterization on the incidence of urinary tract infection and urination rates after transurethral catheterization. The results suggest that the use of catheterization may be effective in reducing infections of the bladder after transurethral catheterization is applied. However, this does not apply to the absence or absence of catheterization.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of gonadotropin-releasing hormone in low responder patients undergoing in vitro fertilization. The results suggest that the benefits of GnRH agonist may be more effective in these women than in the control groups.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of child sexual abuse prevention programs in elementary school children. The results suggest that the effectiveness of these programs may be affected by a number of factors, some of which are more subtle than those that might be missed.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between oral ciprofloxacin and prophylaxis for the prevention of infection in patients with acute leukaemia and granulocytopenic patients with cancer.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of primaquine in preventing relapse of Plasmodium vivax malaria in patients with Plasmodium vivax malaria in India. The results suggest that a more effective regimen of primaquine could be applied in areas where compliance is lower. This could be because the drug is administered in a way that avoids the need for people to be hooked up to the machines.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral dexamethasone combined with prednisolone inhibited polytherapy of patients with infectious mononucleosis.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of involuntary outpatient commitment in reducing hospital readmissions and people with severe mental illnesses.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral borage oil in patients with atopic dermatitis. No evidence was found to support or overthrow current treatment policies.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of oral fluid on gastric contents in patients after the anaesthesia is administered. The results suggest that oral fluid may improve gastric volume and pH in affected gastric contents after the surgery. However, this is based on a small sample size and the results are greatly underpowered to detect clinically relevant differences.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of heparin on outcomes of patients with acute pulmonary embolism when compared with no intervention or placebo. There is no clear evidence to suggest that a mortality benefit from heparin could have been missed with the smaller numbers of studies that have compared heparin with no intervention or placebo.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of oral cephalosporin in the treatment of osteomyelitis.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of tai chi on falls in the elderly. The results suggest that the reduction in injurious falls may be related to the promotion of safe footwear and the use of exercise in the elderly.
We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between DFX and oral iron excretion for the outcomes examined in this review. Results do not apply to absence or absence of chelation.

We have not found evidence that prophylactic antibiotics rive are effective in reducing the incidence of endomyometritis after forceps delivery. There is a small but statistically significant difference between the groups.
We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between sinus irrigation and FESS for the outcomes examined in this review.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of sacral nerve stimulation in patients with fecal incontinence. The results suggest that the benefits of sacral nerve stimulation may be more effective in selected patients than in other studies.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of manual aspiration of air compared with chest tube drainage in the first episodes of primary spontaneous pneumothorax.

We have not found evidence that cold therapy reduces swelling of the knee as compared with TENS therapy or local heat in affected patients. However, this could be because the results are more equivocal.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral ciprofloxacin for the treatment of uncomplicated typhoid fever.

Current evidence does not demonstrate a mortality benefit from prophylactic variceal ligation in patients with cirrhosis and high-risk esophageal varices. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of propranolol in the prevention of variceal bleeding in patients with cirrhosis and high-risk esophageal varices.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit from antiwei treatment was lost in the absence of evidence.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of vitamin E on the cataract. The results suggest that the benefits of vitamin E may be diminished or eliminated when compared with no intervention or placebo in the people at risk for cataract.

The perforated spl int gives superior results by virtue of the fact that it does not require to be removed for purposes of hygiene and can thus produce a satisfactory result even in those patients who fail to grasp the technique of removal and replacement of the splint. The results suggest that the optimal treatment of mallet finger is the conservative treatment of patients with mallet finger deformity with a simple splint.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of coronary angioplasty in patients with localized coronary artery stenosis. The results suggest that a higher mortality rate could result from the use of percutaneous coronary angioplasty in these patients.
There is no evidence to suggest that a mortality benefit from lactase-treated preterm feeds exists.

Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from oral omega-3 fatty acids in cancer patients. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of oral omega-acid supplements in the treatment of cancer.
We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between acetaminophen and Nalbuphine for the outcomes examined in this review.

We have not found evidence that a significant benefit has been gained from the use of pre-packaging of antimalarial drugs in patients. While this could be true in some cases, it is more likely to have been avoided in others. The results suggest that the benefits of pre-packaging of antimalarial drugs may be more easily missed in cases where the drug is administered orally or in small quantities.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of interceptive approaches to canine eruption in affected canines. The results suggest that the effective use of headgear may improve the outcomes of affected canines.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of trapezial space on pain after TMC joint arthroplasty. The results suggest that the benefits of TMC Spacer may be more easily accessible than other available treatments.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist before IVF-ET in patients with severe endometriosis. The results suggest that the benefits of GnRH agonist may be under-quoted in some cases.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of oral cobalamin treatment of megaloblastic anemia with folate deficiency compared with vitamin B12 treatment. The results suggest that oral cobalamin may be effective in reducing symptoms of nausea and vomiting and improving serum cobalamin.
We have not found evidence that placental cord drainage reduces the duration of third stage of labour or the incidence of postpartum hemorrhage, retained placenta, and the need for blood transfusion.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of catheter placement on the outcomes of peritoneal dialysis in patients withperitoneal dialysis. The results suggest that the benefits of catheter placement may be more easily appreciated in smaller groups of people.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of hyperbaric oxygen in burn patients.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral taurine therapy of myotonia in people with myotonic dystrophy.
We have not found evidence that eye patching reduces pain or discomfort in affected corneal abrasions when compared with no patching or no patching.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit has been gained from the use of disinfection of drinking water in people with HIV/AIDS. However, this could be because the data are scarce. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from contemporary trials is required in order to assess the effectiveness of the water intervention compared to control groups.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of chiropractic manual therapy on infants with colic. The results suggest that the benefits of chiropractic manipulation may be more significant in the case of treated infants than in the control group.

We have not found evidence that a reduction in blood pressure is effected by the presence of education and instruction in the form of written and contracts in affected people. However, this could be because the outcomes were rather mixed. Results suggest that the effectiveness of the intervention may be affected by the number of people involved in the intervention and the number of people who attend aftercare sessions.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between phenytoin and saline for the outcomes examined in this review. Results suggest that topical phenytoin may be effective in the treatment of leprosy ulcers in patients with simple ulcers.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of paroxetine in adolescents with major depressive disorder. The results suggest that a true benefit could be had from the use of antidepressants such as citalopram in the treatment of adolescent depression.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of cognitive therapy in bipolar disorder. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from larger and longer-term trials is required to assess the effectiveness of cognitive therapy in larger and longer-term bipolar disorder patients.
There is little evidence to suggest that administration of sodium bicarbonate during neonatal resuscitation improves survival or neurological outcomes at discharge.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of CSP and MP prophylaxis of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) in patients with high-risk lymphohemopoietic malignancies. This is based on a small sample size and the absence of evidence to support the use of other anti-GVHD drugs such as Cyclosporine and CSP in these people.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from percutaneous aspiration of uncomplicated, large ALA tracts. This is based on a small sample size and the absence of other evidence.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from high doses of NaHCO3 in patients with OP poisoning.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of levodopa in Parkinson's disease. The results suggest that the benefits of L-dopa therapy may be under-quoted in some people.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of active management of labor on the cesarean section rates and labor outcomes in nulliparous pregnancies. The results suggest that active management of labor may reduce the rates of cesareansection and other labor outcomes in women but does not reduce the satisfaction of women with epidural analgesia.

We have not found evidence that a significant benefit exists from the use of progressive addition lenses in children with myopia. The results suggest that progressive lenses may improve myopia in affected eyes.
We have not found evidence that HBO reduces disability in patients with acute ischemic stroke.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of opioid therapy in treating chronic low back pain. The results suggest that tramadol may improve pain scores and improve quality of life outcomes in affected people.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between antihistamine and decongestant combination for the outcomes examined in this review. The results suggest that oral antihistamine and pseudoephedrine are effective in the treatment of children with the common cold.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of parenting on adolescent substance use and attitudes and behaviors. The results suggest that the availability of effective parenting skills may reduce drug use among adolescents with and without parents.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of antipsychotic agents in the treatment of children with autism and other pervasive developmental disorders.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from self-monitoring of blood glucose in patients with type 2 diabetes despite the availability of effective control measures.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between clonidine and diazepam for the outcomes examined in this review. The results suggest that the two drugs in the current trials are effective in reducing alcohol withdrawal symptoms but that they are not equally effective.
We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between insulin infusion and insulin therapy for the outcomes examined in this review.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of infliximab in patients with severe ulcerative colitis in whom steroids would usually be contraindicated. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of perineal massage on subsequent perineal outcomes at delivery. The results suggest that perineal massage may reduce the incidence of tear during pregnancy and the subsequent perineal trauma.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of antibiotics on the incidence of perineal wound complications during and after perineal tears.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of antiglucocorticoid treatments on people with major depression while the potential for improvement of symptoms of depression is greatly under-investigated. Further evidence is required from larger-scale trials.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of fluoxetine in the treatment of children and adolescents with obsessive-compulsive disorder. The results suggest that the benefits of fluoxetine may be more easily missed in small numbers of people. This is because the trials involved in the trials were small and the results are more equivocal.

We have not found evidence that a reduction in pain is associated with the use of distraction during children's immunization. This is based on a small sample of studies and the absence of clear evidence to support or overthrow current treatment policies.

Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from influenza vaccination in people in long-term care. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of vaccination of health-care workers in preventing influenza infection in affected residents.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of oral glucocorticoids and doxycycline on the quality of life of people with severe nasal polyp. The results suggest that oral steroids may improve symptoms and biological parameters in patients with severe poly polyp.
We have found no evidence to support the current practice of feeding neonates
We have not found evidence that a reduction in HIV infection was achieved by encouraging female sex workers to use condom use.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of Raloxifene administration in premenopausal women with uterine leiomyomas. No significant differences were detected in symptoms related to leiomyomas and hormonal status during the three-month study window.

We have not found evidence that a benefit exists from preimplantation genetic screening for aneuploidy of embryos after in vitro fertilization in women with advanced maternal age when there is no restrictions in the number of embryos to be transferred. This does not apply to the control group or to the patients who had preimplantation genetic screening before and after embryo transfer. No evidence was found to support or overthrow current treatment policies.

Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from oral Strontium ranelate in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis. There is no clear evidence to suggest a mortality benefit from oral Strontium ranelate in postmenopausal women with vertebral fractures.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit from primary debulking surgery is lost or understated in patients with ovarian cancer after interval debulking.

We have not found evidence that plasma exchange improves outcomes of neuropathy associated with MGUS in people with IgG or IgA type gammopathy or polyneuropathy when compared with no intervention or in a minority of people with no disease. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of plasma exchange in the treatment of peripheral neuropathy.
We have not found evidence that a reduction in CSF concentration is achieved with the use of PBT2 treatments. This is based on a small sample size and the absence of outright evidence.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between stapled hemorrhoidectomy and Ferguson hemorrhoidectomy for the outcomes examined in this review. Results do not apply to absence or absence of bleeding.
Exercise may improve people with HIV quality of life but there is little evidence to suggest that it improves adherence.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of carbamazepine in the management of pain in the affected areas. The results suggest that a selective anticonjugulation mechanism may be employed.
We have not found evidence that a significant benefit exists from the use of antidepressants in the treatment of neuropathy in people with painful diabetic neuropathy.

We have not found evidence that a significant benefit exists from structured treatment interruption of antiretroviral therapy in HIV-infected people with chronic HIV-1 infection. The results suggest that the benefits of structured treatment interruption may be more easily equivocal than in other cases. This could be because the intervention of structured treatment is more easily accessible and less expensive than administering oral antiretroviral therapy in a single-center study.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of pressure-relieving systems in the context of mortality and morbidity from ulcers.

We have not found evidence that a significant benefit has been gained from the introduction of early intervention in infants. The results suggest that the benefits of developmental intervention may be under-investigated in true large numbers of infants.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of retreatment on pain and swelling after retreatment procedures. This is based on a small sample of studies.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of Frankel's function regulator appliances on the treatment of anterior open bite.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit has been gained from the addition of fluticasone propionate to inhaled corticosteroid therapy in patients with moderate to severe asthma. The aim of this three group study was to compare the efficacy and safety of BDP with salmeterol and Formoterol in patients with mild and severe asthma.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of mono

We have not found evidence that a reduction in visual acuity is improved or worse after laser iridotomy in patients with angle-closure glaucoma. The results suggest that a more effective treatment of patients with angle-closure glaucoma may be achieved by administering phacoemulsification and intraocular lens (IOL) implantation before and after laser iridotomy.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between topical Nac and topical acid for the outcomes examined in this review. The results suggest that topical Nac and topical acid may improve the outcomes of the studies examined.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between the two groups when it comes to the outcomes of the studies. Results suggest that the two groups may be more equivocal in their approach to treatment of GVHD.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of prophylaxis in preventing percutaneous gastrostomy infections when compared to no intervention or no prophylaxis at all. This is based on a small sample of eligible patients and the absence or absence of evidence.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of hypertonic saline for the purposes of this review. The results suggest that the benefits of fluid preloading may be under-controlled by the administering of sedatives such as epidural anaesthesia and sedatives.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit from primary closure is lost when compared to T-tube drainage.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit has been gained from the use of fluoxetine in the treatment of people with borderline personality disorder. The results suggest that the benefits of fluoxetine may be under-compromised by the use of other antidepressants such as antidepressants and mono
There is little evidence to suggest that the use of compulsory treatment reduces admissions to hospital and bed days in people with severe mental illness.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of polypropylpropylpropylpropylprop implants on soft tissue response when placed in periapical infected sites. The results suggest that immediate implant placement may improve outcomes when compared with delayed implant placement. However, this may be hindered by the differing methodologies employed in the trials. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence is required in order to assess the effectiveness of polypropylprop
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of endoscopic drainage on outcomes of pancreatic cancer during and after surgery.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the addition of debulking surgery to postoperative chemotherapy in patients with advanced ovarian cancer.
Excessive bleeding is a major cause of women with IUD-associated menorrhagia. The results suggest that prophylactic drug treatment may reduce menstrual blood loss and pain in affected areas.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral polypropylpropylac therapy of patients with type 2 diabetes.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between experimental program and control groups for the outcomes examined in this review. Results do not apply to absence or absence of intervention or to the number of participants in the trials.

Exercise improves muscle strength in people with moderate and severe walking impairment after stroke. There is no clear evidence to suggest that a physical therapy intervention improves muscle strength in affected muscles.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of antibiotic treatment in adults with acute sinusitis. The results suggest that antibiotics may improve symptom expression in affected areas but are less effective in preventing and reversing complications.
Current evidence does not demonstrate a mortality benefit from oral treatment of smokers with moderate and severe smoking cessation with varenicline.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of metformin in patients with PCOS undergoing in vitro fertilization. The results suggest that the benefits of metformin may be under-quoted in some cases.

We have not found evidence that a reduction in pain is effected by the use of local anaesthetic during the cervix treatment. Results suggest that the benefits of local anaesthetic may be under-quoted in favour of the more effective local anaesthetic.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of oral naltrexone in the treatment of opioid dependence. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from larger and longer-term trials is required to assess the effectiveness of oral naltrexone in the treatment of opioid addiction.

Current evidence does not demonstrate a reduction in plantar pressure when people with different foot types receive orthotic therapy during functional activities. This is based on a small sample size and the absence or absence of evidence.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of prophylactic antibiotic treatment of newborn infants with central venous catheterization.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of primary peritoneal drainage for neonates with intestinal perforation compared with laparotomy. The outcomes examined in this review are limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from larger and more contemporary trials is required to assess the effectiveness of peritoneal drainage compared with other treatment methods such as perforation or perforation in neonates with intestinal perforation.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of Very Early Rehabilitation on outcomes of stroke.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of surface replacement arthroplasty in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. The results suggest that the benefits of arthroplasty may be under-competed by the higher morbidity and mortality from the use of stem fixation.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of melarsoprol in treating people with second-stage trypanosomiasis with oral DFMO. The results suggest that a more effective regimen of melarsoprol is needed in order to control the number of people dying from the disease.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of vena cava filters on the incidence of pulmonary embolism and deep-vein thrombosis.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between procedures for the treatment of pilonidal sinus disease and those for the treatment of pilonidal disease. The results suggest that the two primary methods of treatment are effective in reducing morbidity and mortality from pilonidal sinus disease but that they are not always effective.
There is no evidence to suggest that the use of flexible catheter does not affect the outcome of IUI cycles.
We have not found evidence that a reduction in seizure frequency is associated with the availability of epilepsy specialist nurse-led intervention in people with epilepsy.
Current evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from antifungal diet in patients with cancer while increasing the risk for infection.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of oral calcimetic AMG 073 in patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism. The results suggest that oral calcimetic AMG may reduce parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels in patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism but that this is more easily achieved than expected.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of hyperthermia in cancer of the colon, rectum and stomach. The results suggest that the benefits of VHF therapy may be more effective in localized cancer than in the more widely-available radiation therapy.

We have not found evidence to support the use of intra-arterial cis-diamedichloroplatinum II with high-dose methotrexate and citrovorum factor rescue in the treatment of primary osteosarcoma cancer in patients with osteosarcoma.

Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from pneumatic compression in stroke patients. The results suggest that the benefits of tactile stimulation may be more effective in the acute phase after stroke than in the later stages of the rehabilitation program.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of community-based asthma education on outcomes of children with asthma.

Exercise is a major driver of dyspnea in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). There is a clear evidence base to support the use of supplemental oxygen in patients with COPD of varying quality.

We have not found evidence that a reduction in pain was effected by the use of Ultrasound guidance when compared with nerve stimulation or Ultrasound guidance whenperpendulum plexus blocks are performed. However, this could be because the two methods are different. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials. Further evidence from good-quality, contemporary trials is required in order to assess the effectiveness of Ultrasound guidance compared with other guidance methods such as epidural stimulation and local anaesthetic block whenperpendulum

We have not found evidence that a significant reduction in HIV risk was achieved by administering computer-guided intervention or by administering individualized instruction to people. Results suggest that the best way to reach out to people with HIV is through interactive video instruction.

We have not found evidence that a reduction in depressive symptoms or the rates of suicidal ideation or other adverse effects from the use of collaborative care in primary care patients with depression.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of education programs in reducing VAP rates in intensive care units (ICU). The results suggest that effective education programs could reduce catheter-associated pneumonia in intensive care units (ICU).

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of aripiprazole in patients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder treated in a general psychiatry outpatient setting. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence is required in order to assess the effectiveness of aripiprazole in patients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder treated in a contemporary, contemporary, and contemporary, polytherapy.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral prophylaxis for patients undergoing transrectal prostate biopsy. This is based on a small sample size and the absence of other eligible studies.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of transperitoneal on the outcomes of radical nephrectomy compared with hand-assisted approaches or no intervention at all in the majority of patients.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of local anaesthetic infiltration into the body during the insertion of lidocaine for the treatment of patients with open carpal tunc. The results suggest that the benefits of local anaesthetic infiltration may be more effective than the buffered solution in reducing pain during intubated and epidural catheterization of patients.
Existing evidence does not demonstrate a mortality benefit from education or incentives in promotion of adherence to treatment of people with latent TB infection after release from jail.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of red cell transfusion in acutely anemic cirrhotic patients.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of interferon beta-Ib in PPMS patients.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of dazoxiben in the treatment of patients with primary Raynaud's phenomenon. The results suggest that oral administered polypropylpropylpropylpropyl drug may improve symptoms of Raynaud's phenomenon when compared with placebo or placebo.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of palatal closure in patients with submucous cleft palate compared to controls or no intervention at all. The results suggest that palatal closure may be effective in preventing velopharyngeal insufficiency in affected patients, but that it is more effective in preventing velopharyngeal insufficiency than in preventing it.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of prophylactic heparin on the outcomes of pregnant women with preeclampsia or pregnancy-induced hypertension.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of foot orthoses in the treatment of people with painful arthritis. The results suggest that orthoses may improve function in affected muscles.
We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between patients with cleft palate and patients with no cleft palate or no speech training aid in the production of sounds or sounds.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between amoxicillin and antacapril for the outcomes examined in this review. The results suggest that the effectiveness of amoxicillin may be affected by the way in which it is administered and the way in which it is applied.

We have not found evidence that a significant benefit has beenaped from the introduction of Cash and Counseling into the Medicaid beneficiary care systems. This is based on a small-scale pilot program in three states. No evidence was found comparing Cash and Counseling into larger cohorts of eligible Medicaid beneficiaries.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral prednisone when compared with no intervention or other treatments. This is based on a small sample size and the absence of other evidence.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of adalimumab in Crohn's disease when no intervention is applied. This is based on a small sample size and the absence of evidence.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of clomiphene citrate on spontaneous ovulation compared with clomiphene citrate or hCG ovulation induction therapy.
We have not found evidence that a measurable benefit exists from the use of music therapy during cesarean delivery. This is based on a small sample size and the absence of other evidence.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the early administering of gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists in women stimulated during ovarian stimulation. The results suggest that the benefits of oral agonists may be more easily missed in cases where the women are underpowered to detect them.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral steroids compared to intravenous MP in people with acute relapse of multiple sclerosis.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of occupational rehabilitation for people with low back pain when it comes to the return to work or functional disability. The results suggest that the benefits of occupational rehabilitation may be more effective than those offered by traditional case management in reducing symptoms of pain when it comes to return to work or disability. However, this does not apply to the absence of ergonomic exposure which could have a beneficial effect on people with lower back pain when it comes to return to work or disability.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the local administration of prostaglandin E2 Gel for cervical ripening.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of botulinum toxin type B on vital capacity in ALS patients.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of intranasal glucocorticosteroid alone in seasonal allergic rhinitis (SAR) compared to the use of H1-antihistamine and intranasal glucocorticosteroid.

Current evidence does not demonstrate a reduction in proteinuria in patients with nephropathy whose increased protein is resistant to spironolactone treatment. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of aldosterone antagonism in the treatment of patients with nephropathy.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of peritoneal dialysis in the treatment of hypercatabolic ARF. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence is required in order to assess the effectiveness of TPD and CEPD in the treatment of hypercatabolic ARF properly.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of ciclesonide and fluticasone propionate in patients with moderate and severe persistent asthma.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit from oral Calcium supplementation exists in pregnant women or in neonates. However, this could be because the trials to date have been underpowered to detect clinically relevant differences between the two groups.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of urokinase in restoring catheter function to occluded CVADs. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from larger and more contemporary trials is required in order to assess the effectiveness of urokinase infusions in larger and more contemporary studies.

Excessive weight gain during pregnancy is a major risk factor for post-natal diabetes in obese pregnant women. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of dietary and exercise on pregnant women and the outcomes.
Exercise and vitamin E supplementation may reduce the risk of cancer and respiratory diseases in patients with coronary disease.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of oral antiretroviral drugs in preventing HIV infection in transgender people who have sex with men.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of laparoscopic cholecystectomy for the management of biliary colic.

Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from the use of pacifier during the first 5 days of life. No such association was observed, however, when our data were analyzed by randomized allocation, strongly suggesting that pacifier use is a marker of breastfeeding difficulties or reduced motivation to breastfeed, rather than a true cause of early weaning.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of dronabinol treatment than during the placebo periods.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of edaravone on functional outcomes of acute ischemic stroke.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of endovaginal ultrasound on the outcomes of preterm labor in women with threatened preterm labor.

We have not found evidence that a reduction in smoking is effected by the administration of bupropion or other smoking cessation treatments. This is based on a small sample of studies and the absence of other relevant evidence.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit from tracheotomy exists inversely proportional to the number of intubation and respiratory infections that may result from the intervention. This is based on a small sample size and the absence of other relevant studies.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of antibodies in patients with ovarian cancer.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of desipramine in treating major depressive disorder (MDD) in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of Vigabatrin in patients with refractory epilepsy. The results suggest that a small reduction in seizure frequency could be achieved with the administration of VGB during the active treatment period.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of epoetin alfa in patients with cancer.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between tamsulosin and naftopidil for the outcomes examined in this review. Results suggest that both tamsulosin and naf are effective in reducing urination symptoms associated with BPH in affected patients. However, there is no clear evidence to support the use of either tamsulosin or naf in the treatment of BPH patients with lower urinary tract symptoms.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of magnesium sulfate on women with severe preeclampsia while administering it. Results suggest that the effectiveness of MgSO4 may be affected by the specific drugboxeries in the muscle.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between placebo and diflunisal for the outcomes examined in this review. Results suggest that the two eligible treatments for the evaluation of subjective pain ratings are superior.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of isosorbide mononitrate before or after cervical ripening is applied to pregnant women. The results suggest that the effective use of isosorbide mononitrate may improve outcomes in the later stages of pregnancy. However, this is based on a small sample size and the absence of other eligible studies.
We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between treatment of 405 consecutive patients with Bell's palsy and treatment with no decompression of the affected muscles or muscles.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of antetaminophen and diphenhydramine premedication of transfusion of pre-storage leukocytes in patients with transfusion reactions. The results suggest that pretransfusion of antacetaminophen and diphenhydramine may reduce the risk of transfusion reactions in patients with leukemia or bone marrow transplant (BMT) services.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of oral ibuprofen on plasma beta-endorphin levels and the subsequent analgesia rates of those treated with it and those treated with no intervention.
We have not found evidence that HIT is more prevalent or more frequent in patients with heparin than in patients with no intervention who do not receive heparin.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of polyethylene glycol on colonic flora in children with constipation. The results suggest that polyethylene glycol may improve stool formation in affected patients, but this is based on a small sample size and the absence of other relevant studies.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of pelvic radiotherapy on cancer recurrence in women with Stage IB cervical cancers with negative lymph nodes and certain poor prognostic features treated with radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of platinum guided chemotherapy in patients with ovarian germ-cell malignancies.

We have not found evidence that a significant reduction in caries increment was achieved by administering fluoride to children with high-caries risk while increasing the risk for caries. No statistically significant differences were found between fluoride and fluorides when compared with no intervention or no intervention.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of postoperative occupational therapy in improving functional ability of people with hip fracture. The results suggest that the benefits of exercise may be more effective in reducing depressive symptoms than in preventing them. However, this is based on a small sample size and the results are more equivocal.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of ischemic preconditioning on the outcomes of liver resection. The results suggest that ischemia-reperfusion of the liver may be reduced or even eliminated when the IP is used. However, this does not apply to the absence or absence of ischemia.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of ischemic clamping during liver resection compared with no intervention or selective clamping in patients with hepatocellular cancer. The results suggest that a more effective method of controlling blood loss could be applied during liver resection than the current method, which is prone to error.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of multimodal optimization on post-operative complications and satisfaction in patients undergoing major colonic resection. The results suggest that a more effective management of post- colonic surgery may be achieved by encouraging patients to adhere to a strict regimen of rehab during and immediately after the operation. This could improve pain and satisfaction and reduce hospital stay.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of home-based nutrition education in adults with cystic fibrosis in relation to diet and pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy. This study was greatly underpowered to detect clinically relevant differences between the intervention group and control groups.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of CDP870 inhibitor to RA patients with active rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with inadequate response to anti-TNF fragment treatments.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of Rauwolfia serpentina, phenobarbital and placebo in the essential hypertension.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of anticonvulsants on impulsive aggression in patients with alcohol dependence and comorbid psychiatric disorders.

We have not found evidence that a reduction in body fat is achieved by administering behavioral weight loss programs to people enrolled in the trials. However, evidence does suggest that these programs may improve weight loss when compared to no intervention or no intervention at all.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of Artisan lens on myopia compared to laser in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) or OptiOpt lenses. The results suggest that the TICL is effective in correcting myopia but is less effective than other refractive techniques such as peroxisometry and Slit-lamp microscopy in reducing astigmatism.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral vitamin E supplementation with enzymes and enzymes during the incubation period of hepatitis C infection. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of vitamin E in the treatment of alcoholic hepatitis.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of baclofen on the maintenance treatment of opioid dependence.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of antipsychotic in treating schizophrenia with the aim of reaching definite conclusions about the effectiveness of quetiapine and haloperidol. While there is a small sample size and the overall results are marred by inconsistencies, the overall results suggest that the effectiveness of quetiapine may be more effective than haloperidol in the treatment of people with schizophrenia than in other antipsychotic.
Exercise may improve functional ability in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) but is more effective than other exercise methods in reducing falls in affected areas.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of acupressure and interactive multimedia on Taiwanese schoolchildren when compared with no intervention or no intervention at all. The results suggest that the combined therapy of acupoints and stimulation of the auricular acupoints may improve visual health in affected children.

Exacerbation severity was reduced in patients with alpha(1)-AT deficiency while CT is a more sensitive outcome measure of emphysema-modifying therapy than physiology and health status, and demonstrates a trend of treatment benefit from alpha(1)-AT augmentation.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral iron compared to iron treatment in patients with renal failure treated with iron.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of orthodontic arch wires in resolving pain after placement. The results suggest that the alignment of the wires is more accurate than that of the superelastic wires in the majority of cases. However, this is based on a small sample size and the results are greatly underpowered to detect clinically relevant differences.

Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from treatment of polytrauma with hemostatic agent in patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI) and uncontrolled hemorrhage. The larger the hematoma, the greater is the likelihood that the hematoma will expand on subsequent scans. This could lead to higher mortality and adverse events.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of polytetrafluethylene bypass grafting with vein patches or vein cuffed on limb salvage rates when compared to no intervention or PTFE bypass. There is no clear evidence to suggest that a benefit exists from the use of polytetrafluethylene grafts with vein cuff in patients with critical limb ischaemia. The results suggest that the use of PTFE bypass may improve patency rates in affected areas,
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of antidepressant treatment of symptoms of depression in primary care.

There is inadequate evidence to support the use of gabapentin in the treatment of tinnitus in the absence of other effective antiepileptic drug treatments. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes.

Promoting health behaviours for children of parents with intellectual disability is important in promoting a healthy and safe environment which is a prerequisite to continuing parental custody. The objective of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a home-based intervention that targeted to parents with intellectual disability to promote child health and home safety in the preschool years. The intervention consisted of 50 weekly lessons carried out in the parent's home focusing on child health and home safety.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of CLON treatment of ADHD and tic disorder in children with tic disorders and ADHD. The results suggest that the benefits of CLON may be more easily accessible than in other ADHD treatment methods.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of lycopene in patients with elevated prostate cancer risk.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the withdrawal of schizophrenia from antipsychotic therapy in schizophrenics.
Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from oral beta-carotene supplementation in people with CF.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between the two methods of testing for human papillomavirus (HPV) in women with atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Results suggest that both are effective in the detection of cervical cancer. However, this does not apply to the small numbers of women with no apparent evidence of disease.

We have not found evidence that a mortality rate is lower when patients with severe paraquat poisoning are treated with pulse therapy with methylprednisolone and cyclophosphamide instead of conventional treatment. This is based on a small sample size and the absence of other evidence.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of dexamethasone on the outcomes of women with HELLP syndrome when compared to no intervention or placebo. The results suggest that the benefits of dexamethasone may be more easily appreciated in the case of women with HELLP syndrome when compared to no intervention or placebo when compared to no intervention or women with HELLP syndrome when compared to no intervention or women with no intervention or.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between primaquine and CQ for the outcomes examined in this review. Results suggest that the two are more effective than no intervention in the case of uncomplicated Plasmodium falciparum malaria.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of Spironolactone on blood pressure in affected muscles and arteries.
We have not found evidence that a reduction in outcomes from facedown positioning is effected by the reduction in macular hole size or the absence of prophylactically relevant interventions.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of macrolide in the treatment of rhinosinusitis.

We have not found evidence that a reduction in colonoscopy is effected by the use of colonoscopy simulator. The results suggest that the benefits of colonoscopy training may be more easily equivocal than the benefits of instruction when compared to no intervention or no training.

Exercise is a majorstay of COPD and there is a large body of evidence to suggest that it may improve muscle strength in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). However, this does not apply to the absence or absence of breathing retraining which is more effective in reducing dyspnea than controlling breathing with guided exercise.
We have not found evidence that a significant reduction in seizure frequency was achieved by administering anticonvulsant therapy to people with epilepsy during the intervention or control.

We have not found evidence that a significant benefit exists from the use of oral pruritus in patients with uremic pruritus. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of doxepin for the treatment of pruritus in patients with hemodialysis.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of lumbar disc replacement for the treatment of disc pain. The results suggest that the pro disc is effective in reducing pain in affected muscles.

Current evidence does not demonstrate a reduction in physical activity from the implementation of community-based exercise promotion in people living in communities. There is no clear evidence to support the use of exercise promotion in people living in communities.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of simvastatin in thetreatment of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis.

Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from preoperative ibuprofen for post-operative pain in pediatric patients. The results suggest that a pre-emptive analgesic administration of may reduce post-extraction pain in children.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of acetaminophen in postpartum patients with moderate to severe pain. The results suggest that the analgesic efficacy of acetaminophen may be improved by the addition of the antihistamine phenyltoloxamine to the drugbox. This could improve the overall effectiveness of the treatment of postpartum patients with moderate to severe pain.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit from stroke care monitoring is achieved when patients are transferred to stroke units for intensive rehabilitation or intensive telemetry for physiological complications such as hypoxia. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of these interventions in the small number of studies we have been able to conduct.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit from hypothermia exists in patients with acute aneurysm clipping while reducing morbidity or mortality.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit from oral baclofen is proportional to the number of studies.
There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of sargramostim on outcomes of the two-way trial, which was underpowered to detect clinically relevant differences between studies.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between the two groups when it comes to the outcomes examined in this review. The results suggest that oral heparin therapy may improve DIC more efficiently than can polypropylactically-administered anticoagulant therapy.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of antithrombotic therapy in patients with atrial fibrillation while encouraging them to self-manage antithrombotic therapy. The results suggest that the benefits of anticoagulation may be under-quoted in some cases.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit has been gained from the use of antiseptic in newborn infants. The results suggest that the use of cord care may reduce neonatal infections and cord separation rates when compared to no intervention or cord care.

We have found no evidence that a significant reduction in radiation burden was achieved by the use of selective ordering criteria in the evaluation of patients with acute low-back pain who are at risk for occult malignancy. This does not apply to the absence or absence of lumbosacral spine radiographs.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of coronary angiography in patients with renal transplant candidates. The results suggest that the use of DSE may be effective in detecting coronary artery disease in patients with end-stage renal disease but that this could easily have been avoided with the use of other screening methods such as CaDography or Dobutamine stress echocardiography.
Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from oral fluconazole for HIV-infected women.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of contraceptive counseling on women in the postabortion period. The results suggest that the availability of contraception is effective in reducing unwanted pregnancy and encouraging women's use of contraception. However, this does not apply to the absence or absence of counseling.

Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from pancreatic fistula when placed with an stent. There is no clear evidence to suggest that a mortality benefit from pancreatic stenting could have been avoided or understated in the two eligible studies.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the administration of interferon beta-1a in patients with secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (MS). This is based on a small number of studies.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of polylactide pins for the treatment of radial head fractures. The results suggest that polylactide pins may improve outcomes in radial head fractures compared to metal implants for the treatment of these fractures.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of nicotine patches in reducing smoking in indigenous people when offered a brief intervention for cessation, and to assess changes in smoking behaviour at six months.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of cryosurgery in the treatment of liver metastases. The results suggest that cryogenic procedures may improve survival in affected patients.

We have not found evidence that a reduction in pain was achieved by administering hypnotic analgesia to women in the highly susceptible groups or by administering epidural analgesia to those who were hypnotically treated.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of sterile water in reducing pain during labour and the results suggest that the current method of administering sterile water may be effective in reducing pain during labour. However, this is based on a small sample size and the results are marred by inconsistencies.

We have not found evidence that cognitive training improves memory performance in people with multiple sclerosis. However, the results suggest that it may improve ability to remember information and to improve ability to learn and organize it.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of telephone-delivered, interpersonal psychotherapy in reducing depressive symptoms and psychiatric distress in HIV-infected people with depression.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the implementation of exercise intervention in white-collar workers.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of Aromatherapy on intrapartum outcomes. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from larger trials is required to assess the effect of Aromatherapy on a wider range of outcomes than was examined in this review.
Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from reduction in sodium intake or reduction in blood pressure in people with high-normal BP.

We have found no evidence that a significant increase in HIV infection rates was achieved by the promotion of social media messaging about HIV testing and the associated risk factors during and after the test.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of educational visits on obstetric practices when they are used in conjunction with evidence-based guidance. The results suggest that effective education is more effective than instruction in order to encourage the use of post-natal encouraged clinical practices when it comes to the use of encouraged
Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from high-dose chemotherapy in patients with Hodgkin's disease while increasing the risk for adverse effects such as nausea and vomiting.

Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from intervention in pregnant women at risk for or in abusive relationships. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of nursing care management during pregnancy and postpartum.
Existing evidence does not suggest a mortality benefit from the use of oxygen-derived free radicals in colonic cancer.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of intravitreal ranibizumab on patients with macular edema after branch retinal vein occlusion (BRVO). The results suggest that ranibizumab may improve visual acuity in patients with macular edema after BRVO but not to the extent of that in the 2 ranibizumab groups.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effect of swimming on symptoms and exercise induced bronchial hyperresponsiveness in children with asthma when compared with asthmatic controls who did not undergo swim training.

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of selective cannulation of the bile duct for the reduction of post-ERCP pancreatitis compared to no intervention or no intervention at all. There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of endoscopic intervention in the treatment of patients with acute biliary pancreatitis. The results suggest that the benefits of ERCP may be more easily appreciated in the early stages of the disease than in later-stage procedures.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from oral teriflunomide as add-on therapy to existing stable-dosed patients with relapsing multiple sclerosis (RMS). The results suggest that the benefits of oral teriflunomide may be more easily ignored in such cases as when the drug is administered in a low-dose.
We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit has been achieved from the introduction of HIV testing into family planning services.
Reduction of pain intensity and duration of painful crisis was achieved in treated patients with acute sickle cell anemia (SCA).

There is inadequate evidence to evaluate the effectiveness of tranexamic acid in reducing blood transfusion after hip fracture surgery. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence is required in order to assess the effectiveness of tranexamic acid in reducing blood loss after hip fracture surgery.

We have not found evidence that a significant difference exists between the two methods of closure of abdominal wounds when it comes to the outcomes of the studies. No outright evidence was found to support or overthrow current treatment policies.

We have not found evidence that a mortality benefit exists from the use of prophylactic drug in the prophylactic treatment of migraine. Results suggest that the benefits of gabapentin may be more easily missed in the absence of evidence.
